summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from whistleblower Christopher J Dilorio to various judges and SEC officials, primarily dated in 2020. Dilorio alleges a massive, ongoing fraud involving the SEC, Jefferies, and Virtu Financial (NITE), including criminal obstruction, accounting fraud, and money laundering through OTC markets. He claims his whistleblower information has been ignored or used selectively to protect entities like NITE while prosecuting others, and he seeks to expose this corruption to aid in the case of Dan Kamensky.

connections.description: Dilorio repeatedly accuses Handler and Jefferies of being in a corrupt, criminal relationship with the SEC to facilitate fraud and protect NITE/Virtu.
Handler/Jefferies and Cifu/Virtu are alleged to have orchestrated the VIRT/KCG merger with SEC involvement, knowing KCG was insolvent.
Both are former colleagues at Sullivan & Cromwell. Fishman is alleged to have played a key role in keeping NITE/Virtu operational, creating a conflict for Clayton.
Co-founded North Island, which became a top shareholder in NITE/Virtu. Linked through SunGard and Blackstone connections.
Dilorio alleges a deep, corrupt, and criminal relationship where the SEC protects Handler/Jefferies and facilitates frauds, particularly related to Knight/KCG/Virtu.
Mr. Kim is implied to be legal counsel for Dan Kamensky. Dilorio advises Kamensky to reassess this representation.
Both are described as 'bag men' involved in money laundering through shell companies and convertible notes, with their activities detailed in Dilorio's TCRs.
Norberg is accused by Dilorio of mishandling his whistleblower award application, creating false reasons for denial, and failing to produce the full record.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: The trading 'glitch' at Knight Capital that caused a massive loss. Dilorio alleges it proved Knight was insolvent and was the first of many cover-ups to hide ongoing fraud.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: Virtu Financial's acquisition of KCG Holdings closed. Dilorio alleges the SEC, Handler, and Cifu orchestrated the merger knowing KCG was insolvent, wrote down over $4 billion in fraud assets beforehand, and used inflated tangible book value for the price.

events.title: Dilorio's Initial TCR Filing
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed his first TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) with SEC official Berger regarding Knight Capital, detailing allegations of abusive naked shorting and money laundering.

events.title: SEC Preliminary Denial of Dilorio's Award
events.description: The SEC's Office of the Whistleblower issued a preliminary denial of Dilorio's award application related to the 'Opco' action. Dilorio claims it was fabricated and meant to run out the clock.

events.title: SEC Complaint Against SeeThruEquity
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint against SeeThruEquity, LLC and the Tandon brothers for pump-and-dump schemes. Dilorio claims this involved Net Element (NETE), which he had alerted the SEC about.

events.title: Dan Kamensky Criminal Case
events.description: Ongoing criminal case against Dan Kamensky brought by SDNY prosecutors Strauss, Tracer, and Cooper. Dilorio claims the case is a fraud and that exculpatory evidence is being withheld due to SEC/Jefferies corruption.

keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio, an SEC whistleblower, alleges a massive, ongoing corrupt relationship between the SEC, Richard Handler/Jefferies, and Douglas Cifu/Virtu Financial (NITE) to facilitate accounting fraud, money laundering, and protect insolvent entities.

Dilorio claims the SEC has criminally obstructed investigations based on his TCRs, using his information selectively to prosecute some entities (e.g., Sason, Keener) while protecting NITE/Virtu, the main alleged perpetrator of abusive naked shorting in OTC shells.

He asserts that the 2017 Virtu/KCG merger was fraudulent, with the SEC and participants knowing KCG was insolvent and writing down over $4 billion in 'fraud assets' (naked short fails) just before closing to inflate the acquisition price.

Dilorio links the corruption network to high-profile figures including former SEC Chair Jay Clayton (via Sullivan & Cromwell ties), Glenn Hutchins, Robert Greifeld, and suggests the fraud poses a national security risk through money laundering channels like AQR blank check shells.

The emails are presented as an appeal to multiple judges (Caproni, Nathan, Cave, Jones) to intervene in the Dan Kamensky case, arguing that the SDNY prosecution is a fraud and that exculpatory evidence about SEC/Jefferies corruption is being withheld.
